Controversy Explanation: The College Republicans protested the university's invitation of Churchill because of Churchill's comments about 9/11 victims. A state legislator also said that the university could jeopardize its funding by allowing Churchill to speak. Churchill delivered his speech.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression, Appeased Protesters. The university president said that he found Churchill's views "personally offensive, wildly inaccurate and remarkably hurtful to those who lost loved ones there on that day."

Controversy Explanation: Members of the audience heckled Coulter, objecting to her conservative views. University public safety officers removed six people from the event. Coulter finished delivering her remarks.

The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. A local bishop also opposed the performance and questioned whether academic freedom was a proper rationale for hosting the play. The event took place.
Public Response: None. A university spokesman said: "We appreciate the Bishop's point of view, but we have no additional comment."

Controversy Explanation: The university revoked Churchill's invitation to be a keynote speaker at a conference on race and immigration, fearing that Churchill's comments regarding 9/11 would shift the focus away from the intended subject of the conference.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The director of center of law and policy said: "We felt that we had developed a very good and scholarly conference, and we wanted to proceed with it and that the best thing would be to not have his part of the keynote lunch."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

Students, faculty and legislators opposed  the UW-Whitewater Native American Support Services and the Native American Cultural Awareness Association ivitation to Churchill to speak on campus from because of Churchill's comments about 9/11 victims. Churchill delivered his speech.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university's chancellor said: "It is still my belief that the academy is at its best when it functions as a place for the free exchange of ideas . . . I do not share the fear of words apparently becoming more prevalent in our society."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared McAleese an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement and urged the university to rescind its invitation of McAleese because of McAleese's support for female ordination and gay rights. McAleese spoke successfully.

Hecklers disrupted the performance of the play, The Passion of the Musical, several times, accusing the playwright of racism. The hecklers' tickets were paid for by the school administration, who also organized the protest against the performance by encouraging students to stand up and say, “I'm offended,” whenever they felt that way during the performance.
Students protested Buchanan's conservative views on immigration. One student protester doused Buchanan in salad dressing during his speech, causing Buchanan to end the event early.
Public Response: Neutral. A university spokesperson said: “He [the protestor] could have faced a felony assault charge, but Pat Buchanan decided to not press that charge.”

Controversy Explanation: Wheaton College officials canceled a speaking event featuring Churchill, purportedly due to safety concerns, after learning of Churchill's comments about 9/11 victims.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous).  A spokesperson said: "It is important to have a free and open, civil and tolerant exchange of ideas take place in a safe environment.”

Controversy Explanation: After inviting Malkin to campus, the College Republicans disinvited her out of concern over her support for WWII internment policies. There is some indication by Malkin that the university administration may have threatened the student group's funding if it didn't revoke the invitation.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society declared Dellinger an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of his views on abortion and called on the law school to rescind Dellinger's invitation. Dellinger spoke successfully.

The university president claimed that Moore's campaigning for Democratic candidates disqualified him from speaking on college campuses during an election year and revoked Moore's invitation to speak because there was too little time to provide a "balancing perspective."
Public Response: Mistaken on the Law.  The director of communications said: “California law prohibits us from using state dollars for partisan political activity.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, and encouraged students and others to ask the university president to cut all ties or sponsorships of the performance. A sample letter — along with the university president's address, email, and phone number — was provided on the Cardinal Newman Society's website. The event took place.

The managers of the university bookstore canceled Norton's speaking event in response to student demands that Norton be disinvited. The students objected to Norton's pro-choice views. University officials denied any responsibility for the disinvitation.
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university's director of public affairs stated: “since it was Follett's [the independent book store's] decision to book Ms. Norton, it was their decision [to revoke the invitation]”

Controversy Explanation: Administrators told the organizers of the Washington, Italia Film and Music Festival that the university would not host a panel on campus if Tucci spoke because of Tucci's support for abortion access.
Public Response: Condemn Content of Expression. A spokesperson for the university said that the university can't "give . . . any platform . . . [to Tucci who] act[ed] in defiance of our fundamental moral principles."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared Graves an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of his views on abortion and called on the college to rescind Graves' invitation. Graves spoke succesfully.

The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society declared Downs an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of his views on abortion and called on the college to rescind its invitation of Downs. Downs spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society declared Pataki an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of her views on abortion and called on the college to rescind its invitation of Pataki. Pataki spoke successfully.

The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. Public Response: Condemn Speaker (or Artist) as a Person, Appeased Protesters. The college's president described parts of the play as “objectionable” and said it “isn’t the vehicle I would have chosen.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared Lewis an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of his views on abortion and physician-assisted suicide and called on the university to rescind Lewis' invitation. Lewis spoke successfully.

The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.

The Cardinal Newman Society declared Boxer an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of her views on abortion and called on the university to rescind Boxer's invitation. Boxer spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. A university spokesperson emphasizing that "Boxer was far from a one-issue speaker. She is a champion of human rights and the environment. . . .  She is not all about a woman's right to choose."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared Cahill an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of her views on abortion and called on the college to rescind Cahill's invitation. Cahill spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of Fordham — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — were “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged parents and alumni to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents listed in the ad, which included the presidents' names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. Administrators canceled the play.

Conservative legislators and members of the community complained Moore was "too partisan" and "too political for an election year" and argued that public money should not support an overtly political event. The university rescinded Moore's invitation, claiming hosting his speech so close to the presidential election would be "an inappropriate use of state resources."
Public Response: Mistaken on the Law. the president said: "the school announced that the event, coming so close to the presidential election, would be 'an inappropriate use of state resources.'"

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of the university — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — was “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The event took place.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The assistant VP for communications said: “As an academic community committed to the free exchange of ideas, Georgetown believes it is important that students, faculty and staff are able to engage in dialogue on important issues of the day. The university does not endorse the particular content used in the play but supports the right of students and faculty to be able to express themselves on this issue, no matter what their particular view of it is."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society declared Schumer an "inappropriate speaker" for commencement because of his pro-choice views and called on the college to rescind Schumer's invitation. Schumer spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society took out a full-page ad in USA Today that said the president of Fordham — and the presidents of other mostly Catholic colleges and universities — were “permitting an obscenities-drenched production that defiles students” by allowing students to perform the play, The Vagina Monologues. The ad encouraged parents and alumni to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents listed in the ad, which included the presidents' names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The interim president of the university expressed reservation but then canceled the performance after facing complaints from alumni and seeing a lack of faculty support for the project.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university's public affairs office issued a statement from the university interim president: "There are no plans to produce a public performance of The Vagina Monologues."

Controversy Explanation: The university rescinded its invitation to Gonzales to receive an honorary degree at commencement after students and faculty petitioned the university to disinvite Gonzales because his support for the death penalty and abortion. The college then reinvited Gonzalez to speak at commencement but did not offer Gonzalez an honorary degree. Gonzales spoke successfully.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president called Gonzales "a shining example of compassion and social justice" in the commencement speaker / honorary degree announcements, but then after protests, he rescinded the offer to award an honorary degree but still allowed Gonzales to come speak at a later date.

The ad encouraged readers to register their protest by contacting university and college presidents on a provided list, which included their names, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. Students threw pies at Coulter in an attempt to shut down her speech, objecting to Coulter's views on religion and the war in Iraq. Coulter finished her talk despite the pie-throwing.
Small groups of students heckled Moore during his speech supporting John Kerry in the then-upcoming election. Moore completed his remarks but security ushered several groups out of the stadium.
Public Response:
Honor Roll
Neutral. The university's speakers board director said: "ASUA is not passing judgment. We believe he has a unique way of presenting his ideas and addressing the opposition."

Controversy Explanation: Students heckled Pipes and attempted to shut down the event, objecting to Pipes' criticism of Islam. Pipes spoke despite the heckling.
